sentences: John Peter Farnham AO (born 1 July 1949) is a British-born Australian singer.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: John Peter Farnham was born in Dagenham, England, on 1 July 1949, to John Peter Farnham Sr., and Rose (née Pemberton) Farnham.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His sisters are Jean and Jaquiline, and his younger brother is Steven.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Farnham spent his first ten years in the United Kingdom before his family emigrated to Australia in 1959 to live in Melbourne, Victoria.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He attended school at Yarraman Park State School (now Yarraman Oaks Primary School), Lyndale Primary School and Lyndale High School.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: As Johnny Farnham he performed with local band The Mavericks on weekends, while still attending school, from 1964.

sentences: The band had a five-song repertoire.
section: == Musical career == | === 1964–67: The Mavericks to Strings Unlimited ===

sentences: In late 1965, he was asked to join band Strings Unlimited as lead singer; it was a band composed entirely of string-only instruments, and they had a regular booking at a local hotel.
section: == Musical career == | === 1964–67: The Mavericks to Strings Unlimited ===

sentences: In 1966, after making the state finals of the Hoadley's Battle of the Sounds, they recorded a three-track demo tape with Farnham on vocals, Stewart Male on lead guitar, Barry Roy on rhythm guitar, Mike Foenander on keyboards, Joe Cincotta on bass and Peter Foggie on drums.
section: == Musical career == | === 1964–67: The Mavericks to Strings Unlimited ===

sentences: On 29 April 1967, Strings Unlimited performed as a backing band for pop singer Bev Harrell in Cohuna.
section: == Musical career == | === 1964–67: The Mavericks to Strings Unlimited ===

sentences: Harrell's manager and then-boyfriend, Darryl Sambell, was impressed with Farnham's vocals and offered to become his manager.
section: == Musical career == | === 1964–67: The Mavericks to Strings Unlimited ===

sentences: Initially performing in Sambell's home town of Adelaide, Farnham recorded a light advertising jingle "Susan Jones" for flight company Ansett-ANA and was offered a solo record contract working with EMI under house producer David Mackay.

sentences: Farnham's first commercially successful recording was a cover of British novelty song "Sadie (The Cleaning Lady)"; Sambell had disliked it, as the lyrics were so persistent.

sentences: The song gave Farnham recognition in Australia.
section: == Musical career == | === 1967–79: Teen pop idol ===

sentences: Rofe continued the ploy on TV's Uptight and viewers responded with calls to play the song.
section: == Musical career == | === 1967–79: Teen pop idol ===

sentences: It hit No. 1 on the Australian singles charts in January 1968 and remained there for 6 weeks.
section: == Musical career == | === 1967–79: Teen pop idol ===

sentences: Selling 180,000 copies in Australia, "Sadie" was the highest-selling single by an Australian artist of the decade and became the biggest-selling single in Australia at that time.

sentences: His next single was a cover of Harry Nilsson's "One"; Farnham's version peaked at #4.
section: == Musical career == | === 1967–79: Teen pop idol ===

sentences: When TV Week sponsored the 'King of Pop' awards, readers would forward their votes from coupons; Farnham won the most popular male award and was crowned 'King of Pop' five consecutive times from 1969 to 1973.
section: == Musical career == | === 1967–79: Teen pop idol ===

sentences: The Drug Offensive logo can be seen attached to a television camera in the video clip made to promote the song.

sentences: Chain Reaction produced by Fraser, was released in October 1990, and also debuted at No. 1 on the Australian album charts, it provided three Top Ten hit singles, "Chain Reaction" in August, "That's Freedom" in September and "Burn for You" in December.
section: == Musical career == | === Age of Reason and Chain Reaction ===

sentences: Unlike the previous two albums, where most songs were written by outside writers, Chain Reaction saw Farnham write nine of its twelve tracks with Fraser and keyboardist/musical director David Hirschfelder (ex-Little River Band) along with Phil Buckle (Burn For You) and Joe Crighton (The Time Has Come).
section: == Musical career == | === Age of Reason and Chain Reaction ===

sentences: The sound was less electronic and more acoustic, it became the biggest-selling album in Australia for 1990, and was No. 1 on the ARIA End of Year album chart.
section: == Musical career == | === Age of Reason and Chain Reaction ===

sentences: At the 1991 ARIA Awards, Farnham won 'Best Male Artist', 'Song of the Year' for "Burn for You", and 'Highest Selling Album' for Chain Reaction.
section: == Musical career == | === Age of Reason and Chain Reaction ===

sentences: Full House to Anthology
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===
== Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Farnham's live album, released in November 1991, was Full House, produced by Ross Fraser and Farnham, which peaked at No. 2 on the ARIA album charts.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: It contained concert material recorded from May 1987 to October 1990.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: "Please Don't Ask Me" was released as a single, which peaked into the top 30.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: At No. 1 on the ARIA album charts was Jimmy Barnes' album, Soul Deep, it included a duet with Farnham, "When Something is Wrong with My Baby", which peaked at No. 3 on the singles charts.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: In August 1992, Farnham joined the Australian production of Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber's stage musical Jesus Christ Superstar in the title role of Jesus.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Fellow cast members included Angry Anderson as Herod, Kate Ceberano as Mary Magdalene, Russell Morris as Simon Zealotes, Jon Stevens as Judas and John Waters as Pontius Pilate.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: The stage soundtrack, Jesus Christ Superstar The Album, provided the single "Everything's Alright" by Ceberano, Farnham and Stevens, which peaked at No. 6 in September.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Farnham released his next studio album, Then Again.., in October 1993, produced by Fraser and Farnham, which peaked at No. 1.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Of its four singles only, "Seemed Like a Good Idea (At the Time)" reached the top 20.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: The album won "Highest Selling Album" at the ARIA Awards in 1994.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Farnham never really wanted to try his luck overseas even though he had offers.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: In a TV Week interview promoting the Romeo's Heart album, he said that people had put pressure on him to live overseas but he had no intention of doing so.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: "I don't want to go to America to live", he said.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: He went on to say the pressures for him to relocate "come mainly from other people" but his manager, Glenn Wheatley, has never put this pressure on him.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: On Australia Day (26 January) 1996, Farnham was made an Officer of the Order of Australia, "In recognition of service to the Australian music industry and to charitable and community organisations, particularly those relating to youth."
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: His single, "Have a Little Faith (In Us)", in March peaked at No. 3.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: The associated album, Romeo's Heart, produced by Fraser, was released in June and peaked at No. 2 and won "Best Adult Contemporary Album" at the ARIA Awards in 1996.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Farnham collaborated with vocal group Human Nature to record "Every Time You Cry" which peaked at No. 3 on the singles charts in October 1997.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: Also in 1997 he released a series of three compilation albums, Anthology 1: Greatest Hits 1986–1997, Anthology 2: Classic Hits 1967–1985 (Recorded Live) and Anthology 3: Rarities which all peaked in the top 20, with Anthology 1 reaching #1.
section: == Musical career == | === Full House to Anthology ===

sentences: The Main Event concert was broadcast on national TV and released on video.

sentences: During April–May 1999, Farnham undertook the I Can't Believe He's 50 Tour, supported by Merril Bainbridge, Kate Ceberano, Human Nature, James Reyne, Ross Wilson, and Nana-Zhami containing his son, Robert Farnham.
section: == Musical career == | === The Main Event with Olivia Newton-John and Anthony Warlow ===

sentences: Live at the Regent, recorded on 1 July 1999 (Farnham's 50th birthday), was released in September and peaked at #7.
section: == Musical career == | === The Main Event with Olivia Newton-John and Anthony Warlow ===

sentences: On 21 December, Farnham performed a set for the Tour of Duty concert in Dili for the Australian troops serving with InterFET and East Timorese people.
section: == Musical career == | === The Main Event with Olivia Newton-John and Anthony Warlow ===

sentences: The concert included James Blundell, Dili Allstars, Gina Jeffreys, The Living End, Kylie Minogue, Doc Neeson and the RMC Band.
section: == Musical career == | === The Main Event with Olivia Newton-John and Anthony Warlow ===

sentences: Tour of Duty was the first of Farnham's concerts to be webcast.

sentences: For the 2000 Summer Olympics, Farnham and Newton-John performed "Dare to Dream" during the Parade of Nations at the Opening Ceremony.

sentences: Broadcast of the ceremony was viewed by an estimated 3.5 billion people around the world.

== Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: The Last Time to Tom Jones =
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===
== Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: On 1 January 2001, Farnham was awarded a Centenary Medal, "for outstanding service to Australian music", as part of Australia's celebration of a centenary of federation.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: In 2002, Farnham announced his decision to retire from full-scale national tours after his The Last Time Tour—he would still perform in concerts and record—which commenced on 6 November 2002 and finished on 15 June 2003.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: In conjunction with the tour, The Last Time was released in October 2002, it peaked at No. 1 and achieved 3× platinum sales.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: "The Last Time Tour" was a countrywide concert tour, taking a circus-style tent to smaller towns and filling large entertainment venues in capital cities, it became the biggest-grossing tour in Australian history.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: During July 2003, Farnham worked with Queen to produce a new version of "We Will Rock You" for the 2003 Rugby World Cup, released on his greatest hits album, "One Voice".
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Media reports of Queen asking Farnham to join the band were subsequently denied by both Queen's Brian May and Farnham.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Farnham was inducted into the ARIA Hall of Fame on 21 October with a performance of "You're the Voice".
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Farnham also won 'Best Adult Contemporary Album' for The Last Time.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===
== Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Hall of Fame inductee was Olivia Newton-John, while in 2004 Little River Band was inducted.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Combining with singer Tom Jones, Farnham undertook the Together in Concert series during 2004 with ten shows in Perth, Sydney, Brisbane, and Melbourne.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Duets started with "That Driving Beat" and "Mama Told Me Not to Come", solos from Farnham were "One", "Pressure Down", "That's Freedom", "Heart's on Fire", "Playing to Win", "Every Time You Cry", "Man of the Hour", "Age of Reason", and "Burn for You".
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: The pair did five duets to close the show—Sam and Dave's "Hold On I'm Coming", Otis Redding's "Try a Little Tenderness", Ray Charles' "What'd I Say", Arthur Conley's "Sweet Soul Music" and AC/DC's anthem, "Long Way to the Top".
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: The DVD release, Together in Concert – John Farnham & Tom Jones, debuted at No 1.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Farnham's career resurrection following The Last Time, has entered the Australian consciousness as a touchstone for others who are seen to return from a strongly-declared retirement.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: The announcement of the Farnham/Jones Together In Concert tour triggered an unsuccessful claim for damages from a fan, angry that The Last Time tour was not in fact Farnham's last, as purported in its marketing.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Consumer watchdog the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission took no action following this complaint.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: Farnham made an appearance during the 2005 Melbourne Music Festival, raising funds for rebuilding after the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake at the Tsunami Benefit Concert.
section: == Musical career == | === The Last Time to Tom Jones ===

sentences: I Remember When I Was Young: Songs from The Great Australian Songbook was released in November 2005—it contains 13 covers of hits, written and performed by Australian artists—which peaked at No. 2 on the ARIA albums charts.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: In February 2006, Farnham performed four shows at the Sydney Opera House, with the Sydney Symphony, followed by shows at the Victorian Arts Centre's Hamer Hall, Melbourne.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: These shows were sponsored by Dairy Farmers and a percentage of revenue received from the 'I Remember When I was Young' concerts went to the Dairy Farmers 'Creating Greener Pastures' program to help farmers and their communities.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: A 2006 DVD of Farnham entitled John Farnham with the Sydney Symphony Orchestra was released, it debuted at No. 2 on the ARIA DVD charts and then peaked at #1.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: From 18 February, Farnham embarked on a small Australian tour with Fleetwood Mac singer Stevie Nicks for a series of live shows.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: Both artists had equal billing but, unlike the Tom Jones shows, they did not sing together but individually.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: The same backup singers from the tour, however, were used by both Nicks and Farnham.
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: On 26 March, Farnham sang at the 2006 Commonwealth Games Closing Ceremony, in Melbourne starting with his hit "Age of Reason", followed by "I Remember When I Was Young" from his most recent studio album, "Playing to Win" from his Little River Band days and finished with his anthem song, "You're the Voice".
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: The twentieth anniversary of Whispering Jack in 2006 was marked by an "enhanced" commemorative CD re-release plus a DVD featuring an edited version of the tour that accompanied the album (the full concert was originally released on VHS in 1987).
section: == Musical career == | === I Remember When I Was Young ===

sentences: The original album was the first CD made in Australia and, as of June 2008, remains the highest-selling album in Australia by an Australian act.

sentences: The album contains 11 tracks and is Farnham's first studio album in over 5 years.

section: == Musical career == | === Jack and The Acoustic Chapel Sessions ===

section: == Musical career == | === Jack and The Acoustic Chapel Sessions ===

sentences: In addition to this, the Whispering Jack Live video album was edited down by 20 minutes and re-released on DVD by Sony BMG.

section: == Musical career == | === Unauthorised music use ===

sentences: In 2015, Farnham and Wheatley spoke out against the use of his iconic signature song, "You're the Voice", being used by Reclaim Australia, an anti-Islamic group, and again in 2020 in regard to its use at anti-lockdown rallies during the stage 4 COVID-19 pandemic in Melbourne, Victoria which Wheatley described as offensive to Farnham.

sentences: Band ==
section: == Band ==

sentences: As of 2020, John Farnham's band members are musical director and keyboardist Chong Lim, Angus Burchall on drums, Brett Garsed on guitar, and Craig Newman on bass guitar.

sentences: Backing vocalists are Lindsay Field, Lisa Edwards, Susie Ahern, and Rod Davies.
section: == Band ==

sentences: Previously prominent long-serving members have included Venetta Fields and Stuart Fraser, from the band Noiseworks who regularly performed and toured with the band from 1992 until 2018 when his health deteriorated due to lung cancer.

sentences: Farnham married Jillian Billman, a dancer he met when performing the stage musical Charlie Girl, on 11 April 1973.

sentences: They have two sons, Robert and James.

sentences: Farnham is a supporter of the North Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: After years of performing at high-volume concerts, Farnham has tinnitus and hearing loss, and wears hearing aids.

sentences: He lives on a farm near Bendigo, Victoria.
